events.title: Set Aside Moving Fund
events.description: Establish a dedicated moving fund to cover all costs associated with the relocation. Start setting aside money now so there are no financial surprises.
actionItems: Estimate first and last month's rent (Denver market)
Security deposit (typically one month's rent)
U-Haul rental — one-way truck from Monrovia to Denver
Hotels for overnight stops (U-Haul trip + car trip = 2 hotel nights minimum)
Gas for U-Haul + two cars across 3 separate drives
One-way flight for Josh back from Denver after U-Haul drop-off
New furniture for the Denver place
New clothes for Colorado weather (winter coats, boots, layers)
Home essentials — making the new place feel like home
Decorating and aesthetic touches
Buffer for unexpected costs
events.notes: Starting today. The earlier this fund is building, the less stressful everything else becomes.
calypsySuggestions: Open a separate high-yield savings account just for the move — keeps it visible and earns interest while you save
Denver 1BR averages ~$1,600-1,800, 2BR ~$2,000-2,400 — budget first/last/deposit accordingly
Colorado winters are no joke — budget for real winter gear (good coats, snow boots, thermals). You'll want quality over quantity
U-Haul one-way from LA to Denver runs roughly $1,500-2,500 depending on size and season — book early for better rates
Consider a shared spreadsheet or budgeting app so both of you can track contributions and spending in real time

events.title: Optional Early Home Hunting
events.description: As of this date, we can start browsing homes in Denver. Leases could start as early as July 21st. If we find the perfect place, we can shift the entire schedule ahead and move in as early as July.
actionItems: Set up saved searches on Zillow, Apartments.com, and Craigslist for Denver neighborhoods of interest
Define must-haves vs. nice-to-haves (square footage, parking, in-unit laundry, pet policy, etc.)
Start virtual tours of promising listings
Track favorites in a shared document or app
Monitor pricing trends to understand the Denver market
events.notes: This is optional and opportunistic — no pressure to commit early. But if something amazing comes up, we have the flexibility to move fast.
calypsySuggestions: The Denver rental market is most competitive May–August. Starting to look in April gives you a feel for pricing before peak season hits
Focus on the neighborhoods from the City Research tab — you've already done the homework on which areas fit
If a place is perfect but available too early, some landlords will negotiate a later start date for a small holding deposit
Don't forget to check walkability on Google Street View — listings photos can be deceiving
If you find something amazing in this window, moving early means cheaper U-Haul rates (summer vs. November) and better weather for the drive

events.title: Home Selection
events.description: Time to get serious about finding our Denver home. Narrow down options, take a trip to Denver to visit places in person, make a selection, sign the lease, and set up utilities.
actionItems: Narrow apartment shortlist to top 5-8 options
Book flights and hotel for Denver scouting trip
Schedule tours for a long weekend — visit multiple places
Make a selection and sign the lease
Set up electric service
Set up gas service
Set up water service
Set up cable/internet
Notify Josh's current landlord of move-out date
Notify Candace's current landlord of move-out date
events.notes: The scouting trip is key — photos and virtual tours only tell you so much. Walk the neighborhoods, check the vibe at night, try the nearby coffee shops. This is where you'll live.
calypsySuggestions: Schedule the Denver trip for a Thursday–Sunday to maximize tours without burning too much PTO
Visit your top picks at different times of day — a neighborhood can feel completely different at 8 AM vs. 8 PM
Check lease terms carefully — look for early termination clauses since this is a 1-2 year adventure (flexibility matters)
Xcel Energy handles both electric and gas in most of Denver — one less account to set up
For internet, check if the building has Comcast/Xfinity fiber or if you can get a local provider. Denver has decent fiber coverage in newer buildings
Give landlords 60 days notice even if your lease only requires 30 — leaves room for flexibility and goodwill
Take photos and notes at every tour — they'll all blur together after the 5th one

events.title: Research Denver Doctors
events.description: Research and identify doctors in Denver who will be good fits for both Josh and Candace's medical needs. Notify current providers about the move and get their recommendations.
actionItems: Find a primary care doctor for Josh
Find an HAE specialist for Candace
Find a primary care doctor for Candace
Find a gynecologist for Candace
Find a cardiologist for Candace
Find a neurologist for Candace
Notify Dr. Reidl about the move — ask for Denver provider recommendations
Notify Tiana about the move — ask for Denver provider recommendations
Schedule genetic testing for Candace's HAE in San Diego
Plan San Diego trip for HAE genetic testing
events.notes: The HAE genetic testing in San Diego should be done before the move while it's still a short trip. Dr. Reidl and Tiana may have professional networks or know colleagues in Denver — their referrals could be invaluable.
calypsySuggestions: Denver has National Jewish Health — one of the top respiratory/immunology centers in the country. They may have HAE specialists or connections to one
University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus is a major academic medical center — great for finding specialists across all of Candace's needs in one system
Check if current insurance plans have provider networks in Colorado, or if you'll need to switch plans during open enrollment
The US Hereditary Angioedema Association (HAEA) has a physician directory — use it to find HAE-experienced doctors in Denver
Ask Dr. Reidl and Tiana early (July) so you have time to act on their recommendations
San Diego trip for genetic testing could double as a goodbye visit — make it a nice weekend

events.title: Establish Medical Care
events.description: Begin establishing care with Denver providers. Start with telehealth appointments where possible to get the relationship going before arrival, and book in-person appointments for after the move.
actionItems: Contact selected providers and confirm they're accepting new patients
Schedule telehealth introductory appointments where available
Request medical records transfers from all current providers
Get copies of all prescriptions and ensure adequate supply for the transition
Book in-person new patient appointments for November/December
Verify insurance coverage for all selected providers
Set up patient portal accounts with new providers
events.notes: Starting with telemed gives a 3+ month head start on building relationships with new doctors. In-person appointments can be booked for the weeks after arrival in mid-November.
calypsySuggestions: Many specialists have 2-3 month wait times for new patients — booking in August for November appointments is actually right on time
Request a complete copy of Candace's medical records early — some offices take 2-4 weeks to process records requests
For HAE specifically, make sure the new specialist has Candace's full treatment history and current medication protocol before the first visit
Check if Colorado requires new prescriptions from in-state providers or if out-of-state prescriptions transfer — especially for any specialty medications
Consider asking current doctors for a detailed transition letter summarizing each condition, current treatment plan, and any ongoing concerns
If open enrollment happens during this window, it's the perfect time to switch to a plan with strong Colorado coverage

events.title: Map Out Our New Day-to-Day
events.description: Once the home is selected, start planning the details of daily life in Denver. Room layouts, routines, local essentials, and getting to know the neighborhood — even before we arrive.
actionItems: Plan room layouts — measure the new place and sketch furniture placement
Discuss day-to-day routines — morning, work, evening, weekends
Establish rules for common areas and shared spaces
Find the nearest Whole Foods
Find the nearest Target
Find the nearest Starbucks
Research nearby restaurants — date night spots, casual takeout, healthy options
Locate nearest grocery stores (beyond Whole Foods — Trader Joe's, King Soopers, Sprouts)
Find walking routes and parks nearby
Identify the nearest gym or fitness options
events.notes: This is the exciting part — designing your new life before you even get there. Having a plan makes the first week in Denver feel like coming home instead of starting from scratch.
calypsySuggestions: Use a room planner app (like MagicPlan or RoomSketcher) to lay out furniture before you arrive — saves the 'where does the couch go' debate on move-in day
King Soopers is Colorado's Kroger — it's everywhere and has good prices. Pair it with Whole Foods for specialty items
Denver has incredible parks — check out Washington Park, City Park, and Cheesman Park for your daily walks
For Josh's evening walks: Denver's trail system is extensive. The Cherry Creek Trail and Platte River Trail are great urban paths
Discuss the thermostat situation early — Colorado is dry and cold, and everyone has different comfort levels. This prevents the #1 roommate argument
Make a shared Google Map with pins for all your new essentials — visual and easy to reference those first weeks

events.title: Pack Candace's Apartment
events.description: Pack everything in Candace's apartment into boxes, wrap all furniture in padding. Leave only a temporary bed (air mattress) and a folding table to work on.
actionItems: Buy packing supplies — boxes, tape, bubble wrap, furniture pads
Sort belongings: keep, donate, trash
Pack room by room, label every box by room + contents
Wrap all furniture in moving blankets/padding
Set up air mattress and folding table as temporary living setup
Schedule donation pickup for anything not coming
events.notes: Start early and pace it — a full month gives breathing room but it goes fast. Prioritize rarely-used rooms first, leave kitchen and bedroom basics for last.
calypsySuggestions: Get a portable clothing rack instead of living out of boxes for a month — Candace will thank you
Take photos of electronics/cable setups before disconnecting so reassembly in Denver is painless
Consider a small portable WiFi desk setup (folding table + monitor stand) since Candace works remote — work comfort matters even in packing mode
Donate early and often — every box you don't move saves money and energy
Keep a 'last box' with essentials: toiletries, phone chargers, basic kitchen stuff, towels. This rides in the car, not the U-Haul

events.title: Drive U-Haul to Denver
events.description: Josh drives the U-Haul with belongings from Monrovia to Denver. Same ~16 hour route, 2 days with overnight stop.
actionItems: Reserve U-Haul — determine size needed based on combined belongings
Book midpoint hotel for overnight stop
Plan return logistics — fly back or one-way rental car?
Load U-Haul the day before (Nov 5th)
events.notes: Need to figure out how Josh gets back to Monrovia after dropping the U-Haul in Denver. Options: fly back, or have someone follow in a car.
calypsySuggestions: Book the U-Haul ASAP — November is peak moving season and availability gets tight
Consider booking a one-way flight back from Denver (DEN → LAX/BUR) in advance for the best price
The I-15 N → I-70 E route through Utah is gorgeous but watch for weather in early November — check passes before departure
Get U-Haul insurance — peace of mind for a 16-hour drive with everything you own
Load heaviest items first (furniture) and secure everything with ratchet straps, not bungees

events.title: Drive Both Cars to Denver
events.description: Josh and Candace each drive their cars from Monrovia to Denver. ~16 hours total, split over 2 days with an overnight hotel stop.
actionItems: Book midpoint hotel for overnight stop
Get both cars serviced before the drive — oil, tires, fluids
Pack car essentials: snacks, water, phone mounts, aux cables
Plan the route and share live location with each other
events.notes: Need to book hotel at midpoint (likely Las Vegas or St. George, UT area). This is the final goodbye to Monrovia!
calypsySuggestions: Make it a mini road trip — pick a fun dinner spot at the midpoint hotel city
Walkie-talkie apps (like Zello) are great for car-to-car communication without burning phone battery on calls
Each car should have a basic emergency kit: jumper cables, flashlight, first aid
Fill up before leaving — gas is cheaper in CA than along I-15 through Nevada/Utah
Consider leaving early AM (5-6 AM) to maximize daylight driving and arrive at the hotel at a reasonable hour

events.title: Update All the Admin
events.description: Handle all the administrative updates that come with moving states. Update work addresses, get Colorado IDs, handle vehicle registration, and update addresses everywhere.
actionItems: Update work address to Candace's parents' house in Pasadena
Candace gets a Colorado driver's license
Vehicle registration in Colorado (optional)
Update auto insurance for Colorado
Update address with all banks and financial institutions
Update address on all apps and subscriptions
Set up USPS mail forwarding from both old addresses
Update voter registration
Update address with employers for tax purposes
events.notes: Using Candace's parents' house in Pasadena as the work address keeps things simple. Colorado gives 90 days to get a new license after establishing residency.
calypsySuggestions: Colorado DMV lets you schedule appointments online — do it immediately, walk-in waits can be brutal
Colorado requires emissions testing for vehicle registration in the Denver metro area — budget time for that
Keep the Pasadena work address strategy clean — make sure employers are aware for state tax withholding purposes (CO vs. CA income tax)
Make a master checklist of every account/subscription that has your address — you'll forget some otherwise. Check email for shipping confirmations to jog your memory
Colorado income tax is a flat 4.4% vs. California's progressive rate — you'll likely see a nice bump in take-home pay

events.title: Set Up the Core of the Home
events.description: First week in the new place — unpack the essentials, build and place major furniture, get the home functional and livable.
actionItems: Unload and place all major furniture
Assemble bed frames, desks, shelving
Set up kitchen essentials — unpack dishes, cookware, appliances
Set up both work-from-home stations
Unpack bathroom essentials
Get curtains/blinds up for privacy
Test all utilities — heat, water, internet
Do a big grocery run to stock the kitchen
events.notes: Focus on function over aesthetics this week. Get the place livable so you can work, cook, and sleep comfortably. The pretty stuff comes next.
calypsySuggestions: Prioritize the bedroom and work stations — sleep and productivity are non-negotiable from day one
Denver in mid-November averages highs of 45°F and lows of 22°F — make sure the heat is working before you unpack anything else
Do the grocery run on day one — you'll be exhausted and hungry. Stock easy meals for the first few days
IKEA in Centennial is about 20 min from central Denver if you need any quick furniture fills
Set up internet first thing — both of you work remote. Call ahead to confirm the install date aligns with move-in

events.title: Make the Place a Home
events.description: The fun part — add all the personal touches, decorating, art, plants, lighting, and aesthetic details that turn an apartment into your home.
actionItems: Hang art and photos
Add lighting — lamps, string lights, ambient touches
Get plants for each room
Add throw pillows, blankets, rugs
Set up entertainment area — TV, speakers, cozy seating
Organize closets and storage
Add kitchen personality — spice rack, cookbooks on display, nice dishware
Create a cozy reading/relaxation nook
events.notes: No rush on this — it's meant to happen organically over the first 6 weeks. Enjoy the process of discovering what the space wants to be.
calypsySuggestions: Denver has amazing vintage and thrift stores — South Broadway (SoBo) is a goldmine for unique home decor
Plants that thrive in Denver's dry climate: pothos, snake plants, ZZ plants, succulents. Skip the ferns — they'll hate the low humidity
Consider a humidifier — coming from SoCal, the dry Colorado air will hit different. Your skin, your plants, and your sinuses will thank you
Don't buy everything at once — let the space tell you what it needs as you live in it
First Christmas in the new place! Make it special — get a tree, make it a tradition from day one 🎄
